This policy is provided to set out in clear and transparent terms Liverpool City 
Council’s (LCC) approach to charging for all non -residential social care provision.  
This includes mental health (excluding S.117), physical disability, learning disability 
and older people services. The document aims to provide information in an 
accessible format for people, advisors and staff administering the charges. It is 
hoped that the information will support people in understanding the scheme and help 
them make informed  choices about paying for care.

The law allows LCC to charge for care and support - typically in the person’s own 
home - as well as for the costs of residential care. This policy and guidance rela te to 
non-residential social care provision only. The person may also receive a Direct 
Payment to purchase and manage their own care and be required to contribute to 
the costs.   
3.2 When is it appropriate to charge

8 of this policy and guidance.

[Page 19 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]

Page 18 of 21 11 Contributing towards your care costs  
Your direct payment will be made minus any financial contribution that you may be 
asked to make. Your contribution will be decided as a result of a financial 
assessment. This will calculate how much you can afford to contribute toward the 
cost of your care. More information on contributions is available on the council 
website at liverpool.gov.uk/payingforcare.  
In most cases you will be asked to deposit your contribution into your direct 
payments account. You will receive a statement from us telling you how much you 
have to pay every four weeks.

answer:
Residents in Liverpool may be required to pay for non-residential care services based on a financial assessment conducted by Liverpool City Council. The assessment determines the individual's contribution towards the cost of their care, ensuring that no one is left with less than the Minimum Income Guarantee (MIG) after charges are applied.

**Key Details:**
- **Financial Assessment:** Residents receiving chargeable care packages undergo a financial assessment to determine their contribution. This includes a benefits maximisation check to ensure they receive all entitled benefits (Document 2).
- **Contribution Limits:** The assessed charge is the maximum amount a person would be asked to pay, and it cannot exceed the actual cost of providing the care (Document 3).
- **Capital Threshold:** Individuals with capital over £23,250 may be charged an administration fee for arranging care, though each case is considered individually (Document 1).
- **Direct Payments:** Residents can receive direct payments to manage their own care, with contributions deducted based on the financial assessment (Document 10).

**Practical Next Steps:**
- For more detailed information on care charges and financial assessments, visit the Liverpool City Council's website at [liverpool.gov.uk/payingforcare](https://www.liverpool.gov.uk/payingforcare).
- Residents can contact Liverpool City Council for assistance with financial assessments or to discuss their specific circumstances.

The available documents don't provide specific information about the exact costs of care services in Liverpool.
